verses.text: Be ashamed of repeating what you hear, and of betraying secrets. Then you will show proper shame, and will find favor with everyone. Of the following things do not be ashamed, and do not sin to save face:
verses.comment: Wisdom literature often encourages integrity and fear of God above the opinions of men. The theme here is to choose righteousness even if it risks social shame, hinting at the importance of confessing one's faith, reminiscent of Jesus' teaching in Matthew 10:32.
verses.sectionHeader: Things Not to Be Ashamed Of

verses.text: About the law of the Most High and his covenant, and about justice to the ungodly, do not be ashamed;
verses.comment: This reflects the permanence and sacred nature of God’s commandments, which are not to be set aside out of fear of others. It subtly points to the continuity of divine law through history and the covenant's fulfillment in Christ (see Matt. 5:17).

verses.text: Nor about rendering an account before a partner or a journey companion, or about sharing an inheritance among relatives;
verses.comment: Acknowledges the daily realities of honest dealings; followers of God should remain above reproach in financial and relational matters, mirroring the biblical value of communal integrity.

verses.text: Nor of accuracy with scales and weights, nor of acquiring much or little;
verses.comment: Sirach encourages honest business practices, emphasizing the importance of integrity in commercial dealings, reflecting themes seen in Leviticus 19:35-36 and Proverbs 11:1.

verses.text: of profit from dealing with merchants, and of frequent disciplining of children, and of drawing blood from the back of a wicked slave.
verses.comment: This verse reflects ancient household and social norms, where practical concerns like commerce, discipline of children (cf. Prov 13:24), and punishment of slaves were openly discussed; it signals a pragmatic approach to order and morality rather than shame about necessitating firm action.

verses.text: Where there is an untrustworthy wife, a seal is a good thing; and where there are many hands, lock things up.
verses.comment: The admonition to place a seal where the wife is untrustworthy and to secure goods echoes concerns for the protection of property and reputation within patriarchal households of the era.

verses.text: When you make a deposit, be sure it is counted and weighed, and when you give or receive, put it all in writing.
verses.comment: Accuracy and documentation in all financial transactions are urged, underscoring a wisdom tradition that values accountability similar to Proverbs 16:11 and practices in ancient business.

verses.text: Do not be ashamed to correct the stupid or foolish or the aged who are guilty of sexual immorality. Then you will show your sound training, and will be approved by all.
verses.comment: Sirach advocates for moral responsibility regardless of age or status, emphasizing the courage required to confront unethical behavior (cf. Lev 19:17), and teaching that wise correction demonstrates true training and integrity.

verses.text: A daughter is a secret anxiety to her father, and worry over her robs him of sleep; when she is young, for fear she may not marry, or if married, for fear she may be disliked;
verses.comment: A father's anxiety over his daughter's future reflects ancient social realities where a woman's marital status greatly affected family honor and security (cf. Tobit 6:13-15).

verses.text: while a virgin, for fear she may be seduced and become pregnant in her father’s house; or having a husband, for fear she may go astray, or, though married, for fear she may be barren.
verses.comment: Concerns about a daughter's virtue and fertility mirror the cultural value placed on chastity and legacy, highlighting familial and social expectations for women in biblical times.

verses.text: Keep strict watch over a headstrong daughter, or she may make you a laughingstock to your enemies, a byword in the city and the assembly of the people, and put you to shame in public gatherings. See that there is no lattice in her room, no spot that overlooks the approaches to the house.
verses.comment: Strict supervision of daughters is urged to prevent scandal and preserve family honor, a concern deep-rooted in ancestral societies where a family’s public standing was paramount (cf. Deuteronomy 22:21).

verses.text: Do not let her parade her beauty before any man, or spend her time among married women;
verses.comment: Instructions for modesty serve to guard against temptation and protect dignity, themes echoed later throughout the apostolic letters (cf. 1 Tim. 2:9).

verses.text: for from garments comes the moth, and from a woman comes woman’s wickedness.
verses.comment: This reflects an ancient view of peer influence. The implied principle is to seek virtuous companions and environments, as St. Paul echoes in 1 Cor. 15:33.

verses.text: Better is the wickedness of a man than a woman who does good; it is woman who brings shame and disgrace.
verses.comment: This verse is poetic hyperbole reflecting the severe cultural context. Sacred Scripture as a whole honors the dignity and vocation of both men and women (see Gal. 3:28).

verses.text: I will now call to mind the works of the Lord, and will declare what I have seen. By the word of the Lord his works are made; and all his creatures do his will.
verses.comment: This passage recalls the creation motif. God’s Word is creative and sovereign. In John 1, Christ is revealed as the eternal Word through whom all things were made—a profound christological insight.

verses.text: The sun looks down on everything with its light, and the work of the Lord is full of his glory.
verses.comment: Creation reveals God’s glory and power. This is a call to see God’s majesty in the natural world—a theme that St. Paul uses to argue for God’s self-revelation in creation.

verses.text: Even to the holy, the Lord has not given full knowledge of all his marvels, which the Lord Almighty has established so that the universe may stand firm in his glory.
verses.comment: Human understanding is limited. The wisdom tradition humbly recognizes that the mysteries of God are greater than man's comprehension—a key point in the theology of mystery and contemplation.

verses.text: He tests the depths of the abyss, and the human heart he comprehends. He perceives their hidden secrets, for the Most High possesses all knowledge and observes the signs of the times.
verses.comment: God's knowledge covers both the deepest places and the inner thoughts. This anticipates Christ’s own discernment of hearts in the Gospels—Mark 2:8.

verses.text: He declares what has been and what will be, and reveals the steps of hidden things.
verses.comment: God’s providence governs all history. Only God knows the end from the beginning and reveals it according to his will—foreshadowing the prophetic ministry fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: No thought escapes him, and nothing is hidden from him.
verses.comment: God's omniscience is emphasized. Nothing is beyond his sight, a truth repeated throughout Scripture and the New Testament teaching on God's perfect knowledge.

verses.text: He has ordered the mighty works of his wisdom, from everlasting to everlasting; nothing has been added, nothing removed, and he needs no counselor.
verses.comment: God’s perfection and unchangeable nature are highlighted here, aligning with later doctrinal affirmations that God is complete and needs nothing, inviting us to trust his providence.

verses.text: How desirable are all his works, and how sparkling they are to see!
verses.comment: Everything God creates is good and beautiful. The contemplation of creation is a path to wonder and worship, which becomes an important theme in later spiritual traditions.

verses.text: All these things live and remain forever; each follows its appointed purpose.
verses.comment: Creation is orderly and providentially sustained. The regularity of creation is a foundation for trust in God’s ongoing governance and foreshadows the sacramental principle: visible realities reveal invisible truths.

verses.text: All things are in pairs, one opposite the other, and he has made nothing incomplete.
verses.comment: God’s design includes harmony and complementarity in creation—from male and female to light and darkness—reflecting divine wisdom and order.

verses.text: Each confirms the goodness of the other; who can have enough of seeing his glory?
verses.comment: All things point to and magnify the glory of God. The natural response is reverent contemplation—leading the soul to unity with God through appreciation of his works.

sections.title: Things Not to Be Ashamed Of
